div.div:
(2)
reconciles
(as it watches for new Brokers
with broker.class = MTChannelBasedBroker)

(3)
creates a channel,
based on the brokersspec.config
and thechannel-template-spec

(5)
updates .status.address pointing
to mt-broker-ingress pods
path: http://broker-ingress..../<broker-namespace>/<broker-name>

(7)
reconciles triggers associated
with brokers of the type it watches
(e.g. MTChannelBasedBroker brokers in this case)

(8)
creates subscription based on trigger spec.
spec.subscriberpoints to the mt-broker-filter and
spec.channelto the backing channel of the broker.
As a trigger sends a cloudevent back to the broker
with the response to the subscriber, thespec.reply.ref
points to the broker.

(9) reconciles subscriptions and
adds it to the .spec.subscribers
of the corresponding channel

(4)
reconciles and set address
instatus.address.url
pointing to the real endpoint
of this channel
Takes requests to /<broker-namespace>/<broker-name> and routes them to their associated channel address (endpoints in the data plane)

forwards the filtered events to
the user specified subscriber
from the trigger API

Takes requests to /triggers/<trigger-namespace>/<trigger-name>/<uuid> and:
- applies filtering (if any)
- send the cloudevent to the trigger subscriber

sends events on failure
after configured retries

Delivery configs (DeadLetterSink, Retry, ...) are delegated to the channel implementation, so mt-broker-filter doesn't do retries because it might be restarted or upgraded in the middle of the retry sequenceand we want to leverage the channel persistent storage (if any) to keep track of event deliverysuccess or failures.

div.span: DeliverySpec configuration are present in Broker, Trigger, Channel, and Subscription APIs.
The channel-dispatcher watches all subscriptions for it's channel type. That way it is aware of the DeliverySpec for a the corresponding subscriber and of the mt-broker-filter URI to send events to.

switch.text: Delivery configs (DeadLetterSink, Retry, ...) are delegated to the channel implementation, so mt-broker-filter doesn't...

div.div:
dispatcher pulls
for events from Kafka

(10)
reconciles its corresponding channel
type resources and configures itself,
so the dispatcher sends new events
to the subscriptions subscriber
(which points to the mt-broker-filter)
